section.title: &kw-hos-tm; &kw-hos-version-50;: Replacing the Data Disk in a Ceph OSD Node

para.para: Maintenance steps for replacing a data disk in a Ceph OSD node.

section.para: The following steps can be used to replace a failed data disk in a Ceph OSD node.

listitem.para: Once the failed data disk has been identified, determine what the corresponding journal partition and the affected OSD ID is by SSH'ing to the Ceph OSD node and using this command:
Example, where the failed data disk is /dev/sde:
listitem.screen: sudo ceph-disk list |grep /dev/sde /dev/sde : /dev/sde1 ceph data, active, cluster ceph, osd.5, journal /dev/sdg3 /dev/sdg3 ceph journal, for /dev/sde1
listitem.para: In this example, the affected OSD ID is 5 and the journal partition is /dev/sdg3.
Determine that the OSD that is consuming the failed drive is still running by using this command:
If the OSD is still running, check the status and stop the OSD service by using this command:
listitem.screen: sudo systemctl status ceph-osd@<osd-number> sudo systemctl stop ceph-osd@<osd-number>

listitem.para: Check if the OSD disk is mounted and if it is, unmount it:
You will also need to remove the mount instruction for the failed disk from the fstab file. You can determine what the failed drive's UUID is by using this command:
Example output, where the UUID 51c32ca1-0ee1-4c75-bfbc-5d113a4b4402 corresponds to the data disk being replaced in our series of examples (/dev/sde).
listitem.screen: $ sudo blkid |grep "ceph data" /dev/sdc1: UUID="45b7c7e8-4f2d-4226-989b-c83e7e9e2596" TYPE="xfs" PARTLABEL="ceph data" PARTUUID="6c37a311-eabf-4872-bd8e-7d426585432e" /dev/sdf1: UUID="1cfb4de2-fe21-4e20-9a6e-ad45e90949ae" TYPE="xfs" PARTLABEL="ceph data" PARTUUID="209b9af4-8d25-4d60-a430-2934ceca6042" /dev/sde1: UUID="51c32ca1-0ee1-4c75-bfbc-5d113a4b4402" TYPE="xfs" PARTLABEL="ceph data" PARTUUID="dfcd410d-9c56-4bb1-93c6-496bae29de5f"

listitem.para: Remove the line in the /etc/fstab file pertaining to the failed disk.
Delete the journal partition for the OSD and instruct the kernel to reload the table:
listitem.screen: (echo d; echo <partition-number>; echo w) | sudo fdisk <failed_disk> sudo partprobe

listitem.para: Remove the failed drive and insert a new, replacement, physical drive. After replacing the drive, wait for some time so that the new drive becomes stable. Ensure that there are no pre-existing partitions on the new disk.
Verify that replacement data disk gets the same device name and then proceed with the steps below to create a new OSD with the replacement data disk.
Make the OSD out, ensure that the OSD has stopped and if not, stop it with this command:
listitem.screen: ceph osd out osd.<osd-number> --cluster <ceph-cluster> sudo systemctl status ceph-osd@<osd-number> sudo systemctl stop ceph-osd@<osd-number>

listitem.para: Remove this OSD from the CRUSH map:

As soon as it is removed from the CRUSH map, Ceph starts making PG copies that were located on the failed disk and it places these PG on other disks. So a recovery process will start, which can be observed by periodically executing this command:
Once the active+remapped and active+recovering PGs have become active+clean then the data recovery can be considered complete.
Now delete the keyrings for that OSD and finally remove the OSD with these commands:
listitem.screen: ceph auth del osd.<osd-number> --cluster <ceph-cluster> ceph osd rm <osd-number> --cluster <ceph-cluster>

listitem.para: Remove the OSD's directories with this command. Ensure you run this against the affected OSD node only.
listitem.screen:
sudo rmdir /var/lib/ceph/osd/<ceph_cluster>-<osd_number>
where: <ceph_cluster> This should be replaced with the name of your Ceph cluster. <osd_number> This should be replaced with the number identified in step #3 earlier.
Example: In the earlier example, where OSD ID 5 is the affected one (and Ceph cluster name is 'ceph'), following command should be executed: sudo rmdir /var/lib/ceph/osd/ceph-5

listitem.para: Log in to the lifecycle manager.
Execute the ceph-deploy.yml playbook against the affected OSD node so that the OSD service on that node will be started:
